awd_titl_txt: Design of Experiments with Dynamic Responses
awd_abstract_narration:
Many engineered systems, such as those in the automotive and chemical industries, have dynamic performance or system outputs. The overall performance of such systems cannot be captured by a single number, but is instead represented by a response profile over time. Conducting experiments on these systems is costly and time-consuming; as a result, improving system performance through experimentation is difficult. This project will overcome these challenges through novel experimental design methodologies for engineered systems with dynamic outputs. The project is expected to impact a broad range of engineering applications. The academic research team will work closely with industrial partners to ensure applicability to real life settings.

The research objective of this project is to improve experimental design methods for systems with dynamic response. The project will make advances in (1) dynamic response modeling, (2) optimal experimental designs, and (3) computational algorithm development. A novel hierarchical mix effect modeling approach will capture both the dynamic behavior of response variables and the effects of experimental factors. At the experimental design stage, the optimal sampling locations of the spectrum variables and design points in the experimental factor space will be investigated. Finally, fast computer algorithms that take advantage of the properties of B-spline basis function and the patterns in design matrices will be developed.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to develop effective, pragmatic experimental design methodologies for engineering systems with dynamic outputs. Such engineering systems are ubiquitous in automotive industry, chemical industry, etc. Oftentimes, conducting experiments on these systems is very costly and time-consuming, and engineering and management constraints need to be taken into consideration too. A well-designed experiment can achieve a higher statistical efficiency with a less cost. 

In this project our research focused on the methodology of data collection; i.e., how to collect the most informative experimental outcomes so as to answer specific research questions such as how to estimate the parameters in system models efficiently and effectively, how to discriminate alternative models by using experimental outcomes, and how to assess the quality of an experimental design for dynamic outputs. Fast computer algorithms that take advantage of the properties of B-spline basis function and patterns in design matrix are developed. The practical benefits of this project go well beyond engineering applications to, for example, experimental designs for medical trials in medical research.

This project is a multidisciplinary collaboration between a faculty of Industrial Engineering and a faculty of Statistics at Arizona State University (ASU). The research outcomes have had impacts on two academic units of ASU by, for example, integrating the latest reserach results into the classes that the PI and co-PI regulately teach, including Mathematical Statistics, Linear Models, Reliability Engineering and Design of Experiments. Ten journal articles and ten refereed conference papers had been published and many conference presentations had been given during the project implementation period. Tutorials were also developed and delivered on international technical conferences. Two doctoral students were supported by this project. After their graduation, one of them joined in a leading medical research company as a senior data scientist and the other one joined an oversea university as an assistant professor.


Last Modified: 10/21/2021
Modified by: Rong Pan
